CatDescriptText: Mr. Robert Manuez, shoeshiner, Fifth Ward and Mrs. Elva Minor, housewife, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 1, 1961, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think ethnic groups (like the Negro people) profit more by voting a straight party ticket, or are there better advantages for them in splitting a ticket?" Mr. Robert Manuez's answer reads: "A straight party vote will help our people.  I don't believe in splitting the vote."  Mrs. Elva Minor's answer reads: "I think that whoever the man is and what he stands for should be the correct way of determining who you're voting into office.  And this should be, regardless of the particular political party of the candidates."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Robert Manuez wearing light colored short sleeve shirt and cap, standing in front of stone tiled wall; Portrait of Elva Minor wearing floral jacket and beaded necklace, standing in front of window and stone tiled wall
